answers.answer: Hi.I am afraid that the advice you received is pretty much correct--your body feels "relatively hypoglycemic" because it has bene used to high blood sugars for so long. When you are now down in the 100-range it probably feels terrible, right?  There are two ways to go about this:1)reassure yourself that even though you feel terrible(weak, a bit shaky, really hungry, cranky), people do not pass out from blood sugar problems when their sugars are in the 100's. This happens much lower(usually below 40mg/dL). So even though it feels like you are unsteady, this is not likely to happen. If this is your situation, hang in there and know that your body will feel better in a few short weeks, when it adjusts to the normal blood sugar range.2)If you are feeling DIZZY, that may not be related to your blood sugar but possibly something else--dehydration, medication side effects etc. If you feel truly unsteady on your feet, you should discuss this with your doc and be seen in the near future to be examined and go over blood tests etc. If you feel unsteady when getting behind the wheel--don't do it. Have someone else drive you.I hope this helps. Please take care and talk to your doc again soon.

question: Hello there.  This is my first time asking a question here.  I am a recetnly diagnoised Diabetes type II, 40 years old.  My initial levels were in the high 300s.  I can now, with food and meds, get them in the normal range.   Only problem is when I'm in the normal range I'm feeling very Hypo as well.  My reactions are to eat something to bring it up again.  Called the doc and talked to the nurse who told me not to eat.... "that my body has to adjust to the normal range".  I'm schedualed to see her and am starting to think she is a moron and I should cancel it.  Baslcily she told me to stay at work and feel dizzy... oh and drive home just like that too.....
title: Normal BG levels are not good
